column1: As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers
column2: she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys
column3: and then the why nots." By asking questions
column4: Johnson began to stand out.Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects
column5: so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually
column6: she was recognized as a leader
column7: and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.In 1958
column8: NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter
column9: Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path
column11: for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land
column12: but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!
